Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Sulfur-infused carbon nanostructures for High Energy Density Secondary Batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposed Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop a novel nano- scale process for synthesizing sulfur-infused carbon composite cathode materials to produce high- energy density lithium-sulfur (Li-S) secondary batteries with a high rate of charge/discharge and extraordinarily long cycle life. Lithium-sulfur batteries with a long cycle-life are a potentially disruptive technology in the $11-$13 billion lithium-ion battery market because of their three to fourfold energy density advantage over existing chemistry platforms. The technical objectives of this Phase II proposal include the optimization of the electrochemical performance of Sulfur-Carbon composite materials as well developing and implementing scalable unit processes for materials and cell manufacturing. This project will assemble and test pouch cells in sufficient quantities to demonstrate >600Wh/kg operation for 700 cycles with minimal product-to-product variability and reliable performance. Success in Phase II will provide an important pathway to receiving institutional venture funding and building joint-development partnerships to successfully transition NOHMs unique Li-S battery technology to commercial markets.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is significant. Secondary lithium-sulfur batteries employing sulfur as the cathode and metallic lithium as the anode offers the highest energy storage potential of any two solid elements. They offer more than twice the specific energy of currently deployed lithium ion battery technology with half the weight. Li-ion batteries currently have a $14 billion market and are expected to reach $44 billion by 2020. They account for close to 75% of all secondary (rechargeable) batteries used in portable electronics. If the potential of these batteries can be harnessed and scaled economically, they are expected to disrupt current lithium ion cell technology because of their higher energy density and the low cost and wide-spread availability of sulfur. Li-S batteries could transform the mobile device market, the electric vehicle market, and energy storage market, enabling greater efficiency and power in all those sectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a need for higher energy, longer lasting batteries for a variety of commercial and military applications. Li-ion batteries currently have a $14 billion market and are expected to reach $44 billion by 2020. They account for close to 75% of all secondary (rechargeable) batteries used in portable electronics. NOHMs Technologies is developing a rechargeable Li-S battery that can provide higher energy than Li-ion as well as safe operation. The Li-Sulfur pair offers one of the highest theoretical energy densities (2.3 kWh/kg) among rechargeable batteries. NOHMs lithium-sulfur battery (Li-S) employing a metallic lithium anode and elemental sulfur sequestered in a conductive carbon matrix can provide as much as a five-fold improvement in energy stored per unit mass, in comparison to any of today’s commercial rechargeable battery technologies. Near term commercial applications will include unmanned aircrafts, as battery lifetimes are increased to match and exceed current Li-ion technology, then larger commercial applications such as electric vehicles, consumer applications and renewable energy storage systems can be addressable with this technology.  The goal of this NSF Phase II project was to scale up the production of the nanostructured sulfur in carbon composite (S@C) cathode material and test cell performance in pouch cells validated by an external test partner. NOHMs has developed a novel proprietary process for synthesizing sulfur-infused carbon nanostructure (S@C) composite cathode that can enable superior specific energy and long cycle life. In Phase II, we have scaled this lithium sulfur battery cathode composite manufacturing process from lab synthesis (gram scale) to prototype manufacturing (kg scale).

With our optimized S@C cathode we have made 2Ah pouch cells that have been independently tested. NOHMs has consistently improved the cell energy density of the Li-S cell and has achieved a cell energy density of 340 Wh/kg This milestone provides a path towards commercialization and deployment of these high-energy Li-S batteries. In addition to the large energy storage capacity of Li-S batteries, there are other inherent advantages for commercial development of a NOHMs Li-S battery.  These include the large natural abundance, widespread availability, and low cost of the sulfur cathode material in the US.

Modified by: Surya Moganty
